repnme.cdata!:
Guatemala - Reconstruction and Local
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Reconstruction and Local
            Development Project in Guatemala were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Lessons learned included: 1) Prepare upfront
            an Operations Manual incorporating key project design
            features, prior to loan effectiveness; 2) Prepare a baseline
            study before the start up of Project implementation to have
            a reference for monitoring project progress; 3) Design
            Project and Institutional Arrangements to ensure commitment
            and ownership at the Government level; 4) Incorporate a
            participatory approach in Project throughout implementation
            to foster ownership and sustainability; 5) Develop adequate
            inter-institutional coordination mechanisms at the local
            level to ensure local governments' participation and
            ownership to improve subprojects sustainability; 6)
            Incorporate incentives to mobilize local governments; and 7)
            Use of a monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system to
            follow through key outcome indicators.

repnme.cdata!:
Guatemala - Reconstruction and Local
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Reconstruction and Local Development
            Project aims to improve living standards and to make
            self-development sustainable for the population, mostly
            indigenous people, living in extreme poverty in 16
            municipalities by transferring financial and technical
            resources and resource management know-how to the
            beneficiaries. There are three components. The communities
            subprojects component finances small social and economic
            infrastructure and cultural subprojects, that have been
            formulated, prioritized, and managed by the communities
            themselves. The second component focuses on financing
            capacity building activities that help municipal governments
            and participating beneficiary organizations to formulate,
            plan, evaluate, finance, and execute projects. The third
            component, institution building, introduces and tests
            innovative management methods to improve institutional
            response and increase project efficiency, finances social
            communications campaigns, trains staff, conducts project
            impact evaluations, and supervises and monitors activities
            of a FONAPAZ (National Peace Fund) project coordinating unit.
